pr_title: [#2244] Skip sendDisconnectedTtdEvent if consumer not mapped

timeline.message:
[#2244] Skip sendDisconnectedTtdEvent if consumer not mapped.

No 'disconnectedTtdEvent' is now sent anymore after closing
the command consumer when it has become obvious that the
consumer had already been removed/overwritten before.
This resolves case A described in #2244.

Signed-off-by: Carsten Lohmann <carsten.lohmann@bosch.io>

timeline.bodyText: shouldn't this compare to 412 instead of 404?
timeline.author: sophokles73

replies.bodyText: I've changed it now that the relevant code to match here is indeed 412. (See also the ProtocolAdapterCommandConsumer#close javadoc.)
replies.author: calohmn

timeline.author: sophokles73

timeline.bodyText:
I find it extremely confusing that DeviceConnectionClientImpl.removeCommandHandlingAdapterInstance method does not comply with the Device Connection API in that the returned future actually succeeds for status codes 404 and 412 but fails for e.g. a status code 404 being returned from the service.
I am even more confused seeing that a few lines below we actually map the successful result to a 404?
timeline.author: sophokles73

replies.bodyText:
The change to let DeviceConnectionClientImpl.removeCommandHandlingAdapterInstance return a Boolean future value was done when introducing the lifespan for the corresponding cache entries, with which 404 exceptions when trying to remove a just expired entry can easily occur (when the ttd has elapsed). PR for that was #1926. With that change, a failure to remove a (potentially expired) entry will also not be traced as an error in the client anymore.
I think the corresponding server method wasn't changed back then for compatibility reasons and following up on this later on was abandoned because of the new command router concept.
I see that it may be confusing to use that client method with having the API definition in mind. I've changed the javadoc now to add a note about that difference.
We could also revert #1926 and just adapt the client tracing to skip logging a 412 error there. If doing so, that should be in a follow-up PR, but frankly, I don't see that much benefit in that, also since the plan is to abandon the device connection API for the command routing component concept.

I am even more confused seeing that a few lines below we actually map the successful result to a 404?

I've changed that now to 412.
replies.author: calohmn

timeline.bodyText: this is the check for scenario B, right (device has re-connected to same verticle instance)? IMHO it would be very helpful to describe this scenario in a comment here
timeline.author: sophokles73

timeline.bodyText:
this covers adapters which use stateful protocols like AMQP and MQTT where the TTD is -1, right?
again, IMHO it would be helpful to describe the circumstances under which this happens here in the comment in some more detail
timeline.author: sophokles73

replies.bodyText:
this covers adapters which use stateful protocols like AMQP and MQTT where the TTD is -1, right?

Most importantly, but not exclusively. There could also be 2 overlapping HTTP adapter TTD requests, the above "if" block getting reached when calling removeCommandConsumer on the 1st request before the 2nd ttd period has elapsed. It's not that important throwing an exception in that case though, since the HTTP adapter won't send a "disconnectedTtd" event. But could be informative in the tracing span anyway.
